Award.AwardTitle: Strengthening Continuity of Rural Education in Biotechnology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The biology department at the college is developing a program in biotechnology that prepares students from a rural community college for transfer to four-year biotechnology programs. The primary goals of this project are to:
1. Develop a biotechnology transfer program that incorporates biotechnology cross-disciplinary laboratory exercises in cell and molecular biology and microbiology courses, and develop a new course entitled Introduction to Biotechnology. The new biotechnology course introduces students to fundamental biotechnology principles and methods, using inquiry-based, interdisciplinary laboratory instruction.
2. Serve as a pipeline linking the biotechnology curriculum between rural high schools, the community college, and four-year universities.
3. Target recruitment of underserved rural science students for biotechnology careers.
4. Establish ties to biotechnology industry in Montana by developing partnerships and business connections between industry and education.

Intellectual merit: The program is integrating laboratory methods in cellular, molecular, and biotechnology within an established biology and chemistry curriculum. In addition to emphasizing cross-disciplinary laboratory experiences, the new laboratory exercises utilize well-characterized proteins and their genes to introduce students to the basic concepts of biotechnology, while allowing them to develop fundamental laboratory skills. Basic laboratory procedures, such as spectroscopy, isolation of macromolecules, recombinant DNA techniques, immunochemistry, and mammalian and microbial cell culture are being introduced in inquiry-based laboratory exercises. Students are experiencing the excitement of scientific discovery while simultaneously learning the essential tools of biotechnology in a collaborative learning environment.

Broader impacts: This project primarily impacts students living in a rural community experiencing continued economic downturn and job losses. The students served by this institution include many first-generation college students. The curriculum provides a path to careers in biotechnology, an industry that is expected to grow in Montana and other northwestern states. Further, the program provides a model for promoting biotechnology education and establishing ties to industry in a rural environment.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through funding from the NSF-ATE program, Flathead Valley Community College (FVCC) has developed a two-year associate of science biotechnology program that prepares students for transfer to four year bachelor-degree programs in biotechnology.  In developing our biotechnology curriculum, we have substantially revised and augmented the laboratory curriculum in our existing courses, and have developed two new biotechnology courses, thus creating a two-year program which is fully-articulated with our four-year university partners. 

To develop our biotechnology transfer program, this project  infused biotechnology into the curriculum of three biology major’s courses, Introduction to Biology, Cellular and Molecular Biology, and Microbiology, and developed two new transfer courses, BIOB 105 – Introduction to Biotechnology and BIOB 205 – Biotechnology Methods.  Biotechnology students conduct project-based laboratory experiments in our fully-equipped biotechnology laboratory which was renovated and outfitted through funds provided by FVCC and the NSF-ATE grant.  FVCC biotechnology students have successfully transferred and completed four-year programs, and are currently employed or have entered graduate programs. 

The biotechnology laboratory facility has provided enhanced opportunities for undergraduate research projects conducted by biotechnology, botany, microbiology, and agriculture students.  Students receive academic credit for their research work, and hone their presentations skills at the weekly STEM student research colloquium.  These projects have culminated in several student presentations at regional and national meetings, including the Montana Space Grant Consortium Annual Student Research Conference, the Western Regional Honors Conference, the Botanical Society of America, and the NSF-ATE Principle Investigators’ Conference.

With the equipment and facilities provided by this grant, we have also added biotechnology laboratory activities to the science education courses in FVCC’s elementary education program.  Students in the K-8 science education courses practice and develop curriculum modules incorporating DNA isolation and gel electrophoresis experiments, and demonstrate their mastery of the modules by performing teaching demonstrations at community schools.

To build local awareness of our program and to strengthen the link between local high schools and the community college, we presented evening and weekend continuing education workshops for educators in biotechnology.  Participants in our “DNA Boot Camp” workshops were provided with supplies and equipment loaned from the FVCC biotechnology program to use in their classroom instruction.   Through this activity, over 400 high school students participated in biotechnology laboratory activities in a three-year period, resulting in new enrollees in our dual-credit Introduction to Biotechnology course.  The partnerships with our local high schools are continuing, and we are growing our outreach to include additional schools within northwest Montana.

The FVCC SCoRE Biotechnology project provides a model for bringing biotechnology curriculum to rural regions, and providing community college students with a pathway to rewarding careers in a burgeoning sector of the technology economy.

 


Last Modified: 10/24/2016
Modified by: Ruth A Wrightsman

In developing our biotechnology curriculum, we have substantially revised and augmented the laboratory curriculum in our existing courses, and have developed two new biotechnology courses, thus creating a two-year program which is fully-articulated with our four-year university partners. To develop our biotechnology transfer program, this project infused biotechnology into the curriculum of three biology major?s courses, Introduction to Biology, Cellular and Molecular Biology, and Microbiology, and developed two new transfer courses, BIOB 105 – Introduction to Biotechnology and BIOB 205 – Biotechnology Methods. Biotechnology students conduct project-based laboratory experiments in our fully-equipped biotechnology laboratory which was renovated and outfitted through funds provided by FVCC and the NSF-ATE grant. FVCC biotechnology students have successfully transferred and completed four-year programs, and are currently employed or have entered graduate programs. Students receive academic credit for their research work, and hone their presentations skills at the weekly STEM student research colloquium. Conference. With the equipment and facilities provided by this grant, we have also added biotechnology laboratory activities to the science education courses in FVCC?s elementary education program. Students in the K-8 science education courses practice and develop curriculum modules incorporating DNA isolation and gel electrophoresis experiments, and demonstrate their mastery of the modules by performing teaching demonstrations at community schools. To build local awareness of our program and to strengthen the link between local high schools and the community college, we presented evening and weekend continuing education workshops for educators in biotechnology. Participants in our "DNA Boot Camp" workshops were provided with supplies and equipment loaned from the FVCC biotechnology program to use in their classroom instruction. Through this activity, over 400 high school students participated in biotechnology laboratory activities in a three-year period, resulting in new enrollees in our dual-credit Introduction to Biotechnology course. The partnerships with our local high schools are continuing, and we are growing our outreach to include additional schools within northwest Montana.
